## Prime Numbers

Integer > 1 with only divisors 1 and itself.

```
Primes: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19, 23...
```

> 2 is the ONLY even prime!

## Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic

```
Every integer > 1 has a UNIQUE prime factorization.

## GCD and LCM

### GCD (Greatest Common Divisor)
```

```

### LCM (Least Common Multiple)
```

```

### Relationship
```
gcd(a,b) Ã— lcm(a,b) = a Ã— b
```

## Euclidean Algorithm

```

48 = 18Ã—2 + 12
18 = 12Ã—1 + 6

slides.title: Fermat's Little Theorem
slides.content:
# Fermat's Little Theorem ðŸ†

## The Theorem

```
If p is prime and gcd(a, p) = 1:

a^(p-1) â‰¡ 1 (mod p)
```

### Equivalent Form
```
a^p â‰¡ a (mod p) for any integer a
```

## Example

```
p = 7, a = 3

3^6 = 729 â‰¡ 1 (mod 7) âœ“

Check: 729 = 7Ã—104 + 1
```

## Applications

### Finding Large Powers (mod n)

```
2^100 (mod 13)

By Fermat: 2^12 â‰¡ 1 (mod 13)
100 = 12Ã—8 + 4
2^100 = (2^12)^8 Ã— 2^4 â‰¡ 1^8 Ã— 16 â‰¡ 3 (mod 13)
```

### Primality Testing

If a^(n-1) â‰¢ 1 (mod n), then n is NOT prime.

## Euler's Generalization

```
a^Ï†(n) â‰¡ 1 (mod n) if gcd(a,n) = 1
```

### Euler's Totient Function

```
Ï†(n) = numbers from 1 to n that are coprime to n

Ï†(p) = p - 1 (prime)
Ï†(p^k) = p^k - p^(k-1)
```

## RSA Connection

RSA encryption uses:
- Large primes p, q
- Euler's theorem
- Modular inverses

> ðŸŽ¯ **Key Point:** This 350-year-old theorem secures modern internet!

# Diophantine Equations ðŸ“

Equations with INTEGER solutions only.

## Linear Diophantine Equation

```
ax + by = c

Has solution iff: gcd(a,b) | c
```

### Example
```
3x + 5y = 1

gcd(3,5) = 1, which divides 1 âœ“

Solution: x = 2, y = -1
```

### General Solution

```
If (xâ‚€, yâ‚€) is one solution:

x = xâ‚€ + (b/d)t
y = yâ‚€ - (a/d)t

where d = gcd(a,b), t âˆˆ â„¤
```

## Famous Problems

### Fermat's Last Theorem

```
x^n + y^n = z^n

No solutions for n > 2
(Proved by Andrew Wiles, 1995)
```

### Pythagorean Triples

```
aÂ² + bÂ² = cÂ²

Infinite solutions!
(3,4,5), (5,12,13), (8,15,17)...
```

### Generating Triples

```
For m > n > 0:

a = mÂ² - nÂ²
b = 2mn
c = mÂ² + nÂ²
```

## Pell's Equation

```
xÂ² - DyÂ² = 1 (D not a perfect square)

Always has infinitely many solutions
```

> ðŸ’¡ **Key Point:** Finding integer solutions is often very hard!
